documents.name: FoodStorageGuide
documents.description: Comprehensive guide for food storage, preparation, and safety best practices for food-related products

data.title: Food Storage and Preparation Best Practices

sections.heading: Understanding Food Categories
sections.content: Our food product catalog includes diverse categories: **Oils & Condiments**, **Bakery**, **Dairy**, **Beverages**, **Proteins**, **Produce**, **Spices**, **Sweets**, and **Grains**. Each category requires specific storage and handling techniques to maintain freshness and safety.

subsections.title: Oils & Condiments
items: Store extra virgin olive oil in a cool, dark place away from heat and light
Keep balsamic vinegar tightly sealed; it can last years when stored properly
Refrigerate opened bottles of vinegar-based condiments
Premium oils like truffle oil should be used within 6 months of opening

subsections.title: Dairy Products
items: Hard cheeses like Parmigiano Reggiano should be wrapped in wax paper, then plastic
Store cheese in the warmest part of the refrigerator (vegetable drawer)
Fresh eggs should be refrigerated and used within 3-5 weeks
Keep dairy away from strong-smelling foods as they absorb odors easily

subsections.title: Proteins & Seafood
items: Fresh salmon and seafood should be used within 1-2 days or frozen immediately
Thaw frozen proteins in the refrigerator, never at room temperature
Store raw proteins on the bottom shelf to prevent cross-contamination
Grass-fed meats can be frozen for up to 6-12 months

subsections.title: Produce
items: Store apples in the crisper drawer; they emit ethylene gas that can ripen other produce
Keep berries unwashed until ready to use; moisture promotes mold
Organic produce may have shorter shelf life due to lack of preservatives
Store potatoes and onions in a cool, dark, well-ventilated area (not refrigerator)

subsections.title: Bakery & Grains
items: Artisan bread is best consumed within 2-3 days; freeze for longer storage
Store rice and quinoa in airtight containers in a cool, dry place
Whole grain products have shorter shelf life than refined grains due to natural oils
Refrigerate bread only in hot, humid climates; otherwise it becomes stale faster

sections.heading: Food Safety and Quality Indicators
sections.content: Understanding when food products are at their peak quality or need to be discarded is crucial for both safety and taste.

callout.message: Always check the 'shelf_life_days' column in our database for product-specific storage duration. This represents optimal quality, not necessarily safety limits.

sections.heading: Organic vs. Conventional Products
sections.content:
The `organic` flag in our product database indicates whether items are certified organic. Organic products typically have:

- No synthetic pesticides or fertilizers
- Shorter shelf life due to lack of preservatives
- Higher nutritional value in some cases
- Different storage requirements (check product labels)
- Premium pricing reflected in the `price` column

sections.heading: Working with International Ingredients
sections.content: Our catalog includes products from Italy, France, Spain, Japan, Greece, Thailand, Peru, and more. When working with international ingredients:
tips: Research traditional uses and preparation methods for authentic results
Japanese matcha should be sifted before whisking to prevent clumps
Spanish saffron requires steeping in warm liquid to release flavor and color
Italian aged balsamic vinegar is best used as a finishing drizzle, not for cooking
Thai jasmine rice benefits from rinsing before cooking to remove excess starch

sections.heading: Allergen Management
sections.content: The `allergens` column in our database tracks common allergens. Major allergens include:
allergenList: **Dairy/Milk**: Present in cheeses, some chocolates, and bakery items
**Fish**: Found in salmon and seafood products
**Gluten/Wheat**: Common in breads and some grain products
**Eggs**: Present in fresh eggs and some baked goods
**Soy**: May be present in chocolates and processed foods
**Sulfites**: Often found in vinegars and dried fruits
sections.note: Always check product labels and our database for complete allergen information.

sections.heading: Nutritional Considerations
sections.content: Use the `calories_per_serving` field to make informed dietary choices. Consider:
points: High-fat items like oils and nuts are calorie-dense but provide healthy fats
Proteins like salmon offer omega-3 fatty acids beyond basic caloric value
Whole grains like quinoa provide complete proteins and fiber
Fresh produce offers vitamins and minerals with minimal calories
Spices and herbs add flavor without significant caloric impact

sections.heading: Query Examples for Data Analysis
sections.content: When analyzing the openmetadata-table-bench table, consider these useful queries:

examples.sql: SELECT product_name, category, price FROM openmetadata_table_bench WHERE organic = true ORDER BY price DESC
SELECT category, AVG(price) as avg_price, COUNT(*) as product_count FROM openmetadata_table_bench GROUP BY category ORDER BY avg_price DESC
SELECT product_name, allergens, description FROM openmetadata_table_bench WHERE allergens != 'None' ORDER BY category

examples.description: Identify short shelf-life items needing quick turnover
examples.sql: SELECT product_name, category, shelf_life_days, country FROM openmetadata_table_bench WHERE shelf_life_days < 7 ORDER BY shelf_life_days
SELECT category, MIN(calories_per_serving) as min_cal, MAX(calories_per_serving) as max_cal, AVG(calories_per_serving) as avg_cal FROM openmetadata_table_bench GROUP BY category

links.title: FDA Food Safety Guidelines
links.description: Official food safety and storage guidelines

documents.name: CookingTimesReference
documents.description: Quick reference guide for cooking times and temperatures for proteins and grains

data.notes: Skin-side down first for crispy skin
Cook until opaque and flakes easily
Move to indirect heat if flare-ups occur
Ice bath immediately after for easy peeling
Rinse before cooking; let steam 5 min after
Soak 30 minutes before cooking for best results
Rinse thoroughly to remove bitter saponins

sections.heading: Pro Tips
content: Always use a meat thermometer for proteins to ensure food safety
Grass-fed beef cooks faster than grain-fed due to lower fat content
Fresh wild-caught fish requires less cooking time than farmed
Organic eggs may have firmer whites and richer yolks
Aged rice (basmati) produces fluffier results than fresh-harvest rice
